dialogue_turns.speaker: A
dialogue_turns.text: ...removing all those glowing currency exchange rate displays from the streets of Kazakh cities. So, they're, uh, tidying up? That's the big news?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...removing all those glowing currency exchange rate displays from the streets of Kazakh cities. So, they're, uh, tidying up? That's the big news?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank has initiated amendments aimed at regulating the placement of illuminated currency exchange boards " they will remain inside exchange offices but will disappear from streets, building facades, and bus stops.

dialogue_turns.speaker: B
dialogue_turns.text: No, no, it's more than just tidying up, A. The National Bank, they're saying these boards are, like, visual noise. And a real safety concern.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no, it's more than just tidying up, A. The National Bank, they're saying these boards are, like, visual noise. And a real safety concern.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...creating visual noise and potentially affecting traffic safety, as excessively bright electronic screens can impair the perception of the surrounding environment," the National Bank explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: A
dialogue_turns.text: "Safety concern." For, like, people crashing their cars because they're fixated on the dollar-to-Tenge rate? Seems a bit much.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Safety concern. For, like, people crashing their cars because they're fixated on the dollar-to-Tenge rate? Seems a bit much.

dialogue_turns.speaker: B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah! They're unregulated, you know, chaotically placed. And the brightness can, uh, actually impair perception.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah! They're unregulated, you know, chaotically placed. And the brightness can, uh, actually impair perception.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The display boards of exchange offices are not subject to regulatory requirements of local akimats. This has led to city streets becoming cluttered with chaotically placed boards. ... excessively bright electronic screens can impair the perception of the surrounding environment," the National Bank explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Because everyone's just so distracted by, uh, exchange rates. Is this really a top priority for a national bank?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Because everyone's just so distracted by, uh, exchange rates. Is this really a top priority for a national bank?

dialogue_turns.speaker: B
dialogue_turns.text: But it's also about, like, dedollarization! They've done all this work to reduce deposit dollarization. And these signs, they kinda undermine that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's also about, like, dedollarization! They've done all this work to reduce deposit dollarization. And these signs, they kinda undermine that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank has done extensive work on dedollarization. ... At the same time, visual information on boards displaying foreign exchange rates does not contribute to increasing trust in the national currency," the National Bank stated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: A
dialogue_turns.text: Undermine? By simply existing? Are people really that suggestible that a sign makes them lose faith in their own currency?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Undermine? By simply existing? Are people really that suggestible that a sign makes them lose faith in their own currency?

dialogue_turns.speaker: B
dialogue_turns.text: It's about public perception! It's about not having foreign currency rates, you know, plastered everywhere you look. It's subconscious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's about public perception! It's about not having foreign currency rates, you know, plastered everywhere you look. It's subconscious.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These changes are not a ban but a step toward modern digital solutions, a more user-friendly urban environment, and the dedollarization of public thinking," the National Bank added.

dialogue_turns.speaker: A
dialogue_turns.text: Or, like, people just open an app on their phone. Which, uh, I assume they still can do?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or, like, people just open an app on their phone. Which, uh, I assume they still can do?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They emphasized that access to exchange rate information is not being restricted: Kazakhstani citizens will still be able to check up-to-date rates in banking apps, on websites, and directly at exchange offices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: B
dialogue_turns.text: Of course they can! That's the whole point. Digital services are, like, real-time. Much better than a static board.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Of course they can! That's the whole point. Digital services are, like, real-time. Much better than a static board.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, digital services provide real-time updates, unlike street displays, where the rates may change less frequently and not always reflect actual market conditions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: A
dialogue_turns.text: So, they're fixing a problem that digital services already solved, then? That, uh, just sounds like bureaucracy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, they're fixing a problem that digital services already solved, then? That, uh, just sounds like bureaucracy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: B
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's a step towards a more, like, user-friendly urban environment. And it frees up, uh, police resources for actual crime.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's a step towards a more, like, user-friendly urban environment. And it frees up, uh, police resources for actual crime.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The article mentions creating a 'user-friendly urban environment' but does not mention freeing up police resources for crime.

dialogue_turns.speaker: A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. From currency signs to solving crime. This policy is, uh, really multi-tasking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. From currency signs to solving crime. This policy is, uh, really multi-tasking.

dialogue_turns.speaker: B
dialogue_turns.text: It's just... it's about aligning everything. Even the visual environment, to support the national currency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just... it's about aligning everything. Even the visual environment, to support the national currency.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the same time, visual information on boards displaying foreign exchange rates does not contribute to increasing trust in the national currency," the National Bank stated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: B
dialogue_turns.text: And, uh, they're still allowed in airports, you know? Or train stations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, uh, they're still allowed in airports, you know? Or train stations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As previously reported by the National Bank, the change will not affect exchange offices located inside multifunctional buildings and structures (including business centers), railway stations, casinos, inside terminals of international airports, or at automobile, sea, and river border crossing points of Kazakhstan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, yeah, the important places. So, like, it's not a total ban. Just a selective cleanup. Still feels kinda minor, B.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, yeah, the important places. So, like, it's not a total ban. Just a selective cleanup. Still feels kinda minor, B.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These changes are not a ban but a step toward modern digital solutions...

dialogue_turns.speaker: B
dialogue_turns.text: It's not minor, A! It's a symbolic move. A step towards a, uh, modern, digital-first economy!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not minor, A! It's a symbolic move. A step towards a, uh, modern, digital-first economy!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These changes are not a ban but a step toward modern digital solutions, a more user-friendly urban environment, and the dedollarization of public thinking," the National Bank added.
